ABSTRACT
This study discussed the role of Mothers’ Union in the Children’s ministry in Kasindaga
Deanery, Diocese of Lweru, Tanzania. The objectives of the study were: to examine how
Mothers’ Union Members engage in the children's ministry activities in Kasindaga Deanery,
Diocese of Lweru, to examine the reasons why sometimes Mothers’ Union members fail to
fulfill their roles in the children’s ministry in Kasindaga Deanery, Diocese of Lweru and to come
up with recommendations to ensure that the Mothers’ Union objective of effective children’s
ministry is achieved in Kasindaga Deanery, Diocese of Lweru. A cross-sectional study design
using a sample of 50 respondents was adopted. Findings revealed that 76% of the respondents
said that the Church prays for the children through the Mothers’ Union members. It was also
established that 46% of the respondents said that Mothers’ Union members sometimes fail to
fulfill their roles in the children’s ministry due to the drought which causes a shortage of food. In
addition, 66% of the respondents said that the Church should strengthen the good teachings of
the Bible about the children and teach good faith by example to ensure that the Mothers’ Union
objective of effective children’s ministry is achieved in Kasindaga Deanery, Diocese of Lweru.
The study recommends that Mothers’ Union must get training on how to lead children in a Godly
way. Mothers’ Union in Kasindaga Deanery, Diocese of Lweru need to develop the church
membership and begin discipleship classes for children. In addition, there should be a mass
sensitization about the need for effective children’s ministry in Kasindaga Deanery, Diocese of
Lweru so that the members of Mothers’ Union and congregants can actively participate in
children’s ministry.

CHAPTER ONE: THE PROBLEM AND ITS SETTING
1.1 Introduction
Mothers’ Union is a worldwide group that brings together all Anglican Women. The
organization was formed by Mary Sumner. “Englishwoman Mary Sumner founded MU. She
grew up in a happy home where her father ensured she was well-educated and Mary was very
grateful for that but, as she often said later, the house revolved around her mother. In 1848, then
aged nineteen, Mary married a clergyman by the name of George Sumner. When her first child
was born, she felt inadequate for the spiritual and moral responsibility of bringing up the child.
She also reasoned that, if she thought that, other mothers must feel that too. Later, when she was
in her fifties, that conviction prompted her to begin a small, local ministry to meet the need.”1
“The Society had its beginnings in 1876 in the parish of old Alresford, Hampshire, England,
when Mary Elizabeth Sumner, the Rector’s wife, gathered together the mothers of the parish to
form a group that would unite in prayer and service, working actively in their own homes for
growth in marriage and the Christian upbringing of their children.”2 History says she panicked
when the moment came to speak of this new idea and her husband, George Sumner, had to take
over. A week later Mary called another meeting and the Mothers’ Union was born.
“MU is a worldwide Christian organisation that is over 140 years old, active in 84 countries, and
has over 4 million members linked by daily prayer. Most members are from India (1.9 million)
and Africa (1.3 million). It is a ministry to help families at their point of need.”3 Also Cordelia
Moyse writes, “The MU is a mass organisation which has its roots deep in local parish life and in
the lives of ordinary women.”4 MU soon spread across social, economic, national and ethnic
boundaries. It helped encourage some women to be less private and more public about their
Christian faith, for example., praying with other women for their children.
Another MU ministry, begun by Joyce Hayman in Sydney, serving tea and biscuits to families
and defendants in the law courts. This ministry began as a three-day-a-week concession by the
Justice Department, but soon expanded to five days as Magistrates noticed the calming effect

In the Diocese of Lweru, Mothers’ Union has been in existence since 2006. The Diocese of
Lweru was formed from the Mother Diocese of Kagera. According to the interview from
Margreth Kyabona “The Diocese of Lweru has 154 members of Mothers’ Union.”5 This
organization has a Vision, Mission, Core Values and Goals to be achieved within a stipulated
period of time. The main mission is the advancement of Christianity in all spheres of marriage
and family life. In order to carry out this mission, Mothers’ Union’s objectives are: first to keep a
community of Christians connected in prayer, worship, and service on a global scale; to inspire
parents to raise their children in the Church's faith and way of life; to defend and advance the
larger understanding of Christ's teaching on the nature of marriage; to encourage social factors
that are conducive to stable family life and the protection of children; and lastly to support
people whose family lives, have experienced difficulties.
1.2 Statement of the Problem
Although Mothers’ Union members in the Diocese of Lweru play a critical role in the church but
their involvement in caring the children in the church is generally poor and this has contributed
greatly to ineffective children’s ministry generally in the Diocese. Although Jesus Christ himself
declared in the Gospel according to Mathew 19:14, “let the little children come to me and do not
hinder them for the kingdom of heaven belongs to such as thesem,” many of the MU members in
Lweru Diocese have not yet responded well to this divine calling. Jesus is ready to receive the
children into his kingdom but some parents including many mothers are hindering the children
from coming to Jesus Christ in many ways, especially by not allowing them to go to church on
Sundays. They leave them behind to keep their homes or they give the children different kinds of
work like cooking and caring for their siblings as their mothers go to the church for Sunday
worship and discipleship programmes.

Accordingly, this dissertation sought to assess the role of Mothers’ Union members in the
Children’s ministry. According to the Mothers' Union's Constitution, the organization's main
goal is to provide Christian women with knowledge about how to lead Christian families, and its
secondary goal is to assist in the Union's economic development so that it can carry out its
activities. This secondary goal is beneficial, but it should not take priority over the primary one.
Many Mothers’ Union members have expressed their dissatisfaction with the Mothers' Union's
current fundraising efforts across the Diocese, claiming that Christian women are becoming
increasingly weary of the organization's excessive requests for monetary and material support.
Despite being duly elected, several Mothers' Union leaders have been accused of failing to grasp
their responsibilities. Many believe that these leaders never had any official education or training
regarding their duties and responsibilities. These leaders have not done much to promote
Christian family life. Since the Kasindaga Deanery represented the Diocese of Lweru, the
researcher used this background information to investigate the Mothers' Union's role in children's
ministry.

The main purpose of this study was to find out the role of Mothers’ Union in the Children’s
ministry, especially in Kasindaga Deanery, Diocese of Lweru, Tanzania.

1.6 Scope of the Study
1.6.1 Geographical Scope
This study was conducted in the diocese of Lweru Tanzania. Lweru Diocese is one of the
Anglican dioceses found in the North Western part of Tanzania, Kagera region, Muleba district.
Lweru Diocese is the 23rd Anglican Diocese in the Church of the Province of Tanzania. It was
established on 20 August 2006. “It borders Uganda in the north and Lake Victoria in the east. It
lies between longitudes 1° and 2.5° S and latitudes 31° and 33° E. The Diocese has 21 islands of
which 15 are inhabitable. The land is well-watered, ever-green and beautiful; with a comfortable
temperature range of 17° C – 29° C. The average rainfall is between 800 – 1,500 mm per year.
The name Lweru is an indigenous name for Lake Victoria. It means an expansive mass of water
spread out over a very large area. The name upholds the eminence and immaculacy of the
world’s third largest lake.”6
1.6.2 Content Scope
The study was an assessment of the role of Mothers’ Union in the children’s ministry in
Kasindaga Deanery, Lweru Diocese, Anglican Church of Tanzania. It was limited to examining
what the diocese of Lweru in the Anglican Church of Tanzania is doing and not doing in relation
the role of Mothers’ Union members’ involvement in the children’s ministry.
1.6.3 Time Scope
Time scope is the presentation of a chronological sequence of events along a drawn line that
enables a viewer to understand temporal relationships quickly. This study covered the period of
2015 to 2023. This is because it was the period when this problem was taken seriously in the
diocese and especially in Kasindaga Deanery.

1.7 Significance of the Study
The dissertation may help the Mothers’ Union members to understand better their role in the
children’s ministry in Lweru Diocese.
The study may also serve as a roadmap for Mothers' Union leaders, members, and the Diocese as
they plan for their Christians, especially the young children who need to be taught so that they
might mature in their faith and participation in church life just as Jesus did (Luke 2:52).
The findings of this study may act as a source of information to future researchers who would
like to do further studies on the topic.
It has also equipped the researcher with more research skills and knowledge about the role of
Mothers’ Union in children’s ministry in the Church, especially in Lweru Diocese.
1.8. Limitations of the Study
1.8.1 The researcher faced the following challenges:
• No response by some questionnaire respondents.
• Language barrier, since some respondents were not well conversant with English.
• Limited time, since the researcher was doing this research project at the same time
studying.
1.8.2 Coping strategies (Solutions)
• The researcher used interview method to get answers to the questions which had not been
answered in the questionnaire.
• The researcher translated the questionnaire into vernacular for the respondents who had
language barrier problems.
• The researcher worked hard in consultation with her supervisor to ensure that she
completes her dissertation before the end of her final semester of her Bachelor of Divinity
studies.

CHAPTER TWO: LITERATURE REVIEW
2.1 Introduction
This chapter reviewed what others scholars have done in the field of the role of the Mothers’
Union in the Children’s ministry. The literature was reviewed under the three sub topics
following the three of objectives of the study which are: to examine how Mothers' Union engage
in the children's ministry activities in Kasindaga Deanery; to examine the reasons why
sometimes Mothers’ Union members fail to fulfill their roles in the children’s ministry in
Kasindaga Deanery; and to come up with suggestions to ensure that the Mothers’ Union
objective of effective children’s ministry is achieved in Kasindaga Deanery, Diocese of Lweru.
2.2 Mothers’ Union Involvement in Children’s Ministry Activities
The role of Mothers' Union is to bring God's love to others through local activities like
supporting children in their own church, or projects and campaigns that everyone can join in, to
raise awareness of gender-based violence. “As Mothers’ Union members we work as a team,
inspiring each other during fellowship. We discuss issues of our children, spouses, and look for
alternative ways of how to handle family and social problems”7
MU’s specific objectives include: “To encourage parents in their role of developing the faith of
their children. Maintaining a worldwide fellowship of Christians united in prayer, worship and
service; promoting conditions in society favorable for stable family life and the protection of
children; helping those whose family life has met with adversity; and promoting and supporting
married life.”8
The lessons learned can be applied to inspire and lead others when children return to their
communities of faith and society at large. “Christian parents play an extremely important role in
helping to nature the children. It is merely to help the next generation know the Bible so that they

2.3 How the Church has Supported Mothers’ Union Members’ Involvement in Children’s
Ministry Activities
The Church’s role in underpinning and supporting parents is vital. The church must support
parents and families so that they in turn are better and able to support the Children. God himself
entrusted his Son to humankind as a vulnerable child, requiring that Son to be natured by a frail
but able family and community, symbolically providing a model of trust and responsibility (Luk
2:41-45).
“The Church, is a physical structure where people gather to worship, learn and to have
fellowship with others who believe in Jesus Christ.”10In another sense, a church, according the
above authors, could be a spiritual community of all people who believe in Jesus Christ. In its
primary sense it means a visible, local congregation, or an organized company of disciples
meeting at a given place and for a given purpose. Therefore, a Church is a congregation of
baptized believers united by covenant to carry into effect the will of the Lord Jesus Christ. The
church has a mandate, among other things, to ensure the total development of their members
including the children. “The church, as an agent of child development plays a vital role, in
conjunction with other stakeholders, not only in the spiritual and moral aspects of the child’s
development, but also see to the social, educational and psychological status of the child through
its (the church’s) peripheral functions. Therefore, an effective faith-based children's ministry

2.4 Reasons why sometimes Mothers’ Union Members fail in their role of effective
Children’s Ministry
Some Mothers’ Union members fail to perform their role of effective children’s Ministry due to
different barriers. These were revealed by the empirical findings of this study that are recorded in
Chapter Four of this dissertation.
2.5 How the Church can ensure that the Mothers’ Union Members do not fail in their role
of effective Children’s Ministry
To surmount these barriers, we need to engage in formal, informal and non-formal ministry
training, adopt more relational approaches, and strengthen intergenerational connections.
Mothers’ Union members should also prioritize family ministry, including children and parents
in the process and practice of ministry, and cultivating mindsets that are open to how things
could be.
Concerning volunteers, as one practitioner suggested, we need to get better at identifying
people’s gifts, and not just getting people to fill gaps. Catherine Booth, the co-founder of the
Salvation Army, said, “There is no improving the future without disturbing the present.”13
Sometimes, the greatest hindrance to a strategic approach to children’s ministry is the barriers we
erect in our minds. Are you welded to what you know? Most religious people tend to love the
past more than the present or the future (the irony is that God is always “making everything
new”14 Revelation 21:5). We must embrace change. Holding onto the past does not give
children’s ministry much of a future.
Yes, change is risky, but not changing is even riskier! If we do not change, we sentence
children’s ministry to stagnation or decline. To surmount these barriers, we need to ramp up
formal, informal and non-formal ministry training, adopt more relational approaches, and
strengthen intergenerational connections.

CHAPTER THREE: METHODOLOGY
3.1 Introduction
In this chapter the researcher identified the tools that were used to collect the data in the field.
These tools included research plan/ design, population, sampling techniques, Sample Size
Sources of Data (primary and secondary), research instruments, validation of the research
instruments, data collection procedure data, processing and analysis.
3.2 Research Design
The researcher used a cross-sectional approach as regards the nature of data. This is because the
researcher aimed at getting an in-depth analysis on assessing the Mothers’ Union’s in Kasindaga
Deanery to know their responsibility and reduce the problems that facing the children’s ministry.
The researcher employed heavily the use of questionnaires and interview guide.
3.3 Population
The Deanery has 3 parishes; the number of people included are 631. The Chairperson of the
Mothers’ Union, Juditha William, the Senior Priest’s wife (Elieth Stanly), Junior priests’ wives
(Febronia, and Neema) and some lay women members of Mothers’ Union represented the bigger
population of MU leaders and members in the Kasindaga Deanery, Diocese of Lweru.
3.4 Sample Size
This research contacted 50 respondents in the Kasindaga Deanery.
3.5 Sampling Methods/Techniques
The researcher focused on the exuded and stratified sampling method in selecting the
respondents. This is because it is quick and time saving. The researcher looked at the reasons that
make them fail to engage in the children’s ministry in their homes and the consequences of their
failure.

3.6 Sources of Data Primary
3.6.1 Primary Data
The researcher used primary sources to collect the relevant data required for the study: these
included meetings, interviews, questionnaires and one to one contact.
3.6.2 Secondary Data
The researcher used different secondary sources during the data collection exercises; the sources
included books, Journals, Newspapers, and the internet. During the data collection exercise, the

5.1 Introduction
This chapter presents the theological analysis of the role of Mothers’ Union in the Children’s
ministry in relation to the Bible, both the Old Testament and New Testament throughout the
History of the Church up to the modern Church. This analysis is done on the basis and context of
the first three chapters of this study. The main aim is to come up with a wider picture about the
real role of Mothers’ Union in the children’s ministry.
5.2 The Role of Mothers’ Union in the Children’s ministry in relation to the Old Testament
Biblical examples can be used to illustrate the variety of responsibilities that Christian mothers
have. According to Genesis 3:16, God created Eve (women) expressly for the purpose of
physically becoming pregnant and giving birth. He also gave women an emotional disposition
that makes it easier for them to bond with and care for their offspring. Paul references the fifth
commandment, which is for children to reverence their parents, in Exodus 20:12 in verse 20. In
verse 21, fathers are admonished to control their rage and any other hostile feelings they may
have towards their children. Deuteronomy 4:9; Deuteronomy 6:7-9; Deuteronomy 11:18-19 and
Psalm 71:18 elaborate the concept of rearing and teaching children along with the scriptural
mandates of the Bible. Therefore, it indicates that the parents are the ones with the primary
responsibility of rearing children, while the society and the church come the second. Hence, the
responsibility lies with the parents in fulfilling their biblical responsibilities. This relates very
closely with the role of the Mothers’ Union Organization in their responsibility to model
Christian families according to their objectives.
Many parents leave their children at home and do not give them priority to worship in church as
the results children fail to have time of gathering in the church to worship and share the word of
God together as we see in the book of proverb 22:6 “train a child in the way he should go and
when he is old e will not turn from it” this means this verse explains how to raise a child in
morals and in Christian life. Furthermore, Mothers’ Union members should encourage parents to
bring up their children in the faith and life of the Church of Christ by teaching them at home.

CHAPTER SIX: CONCLUSION AND RECOMMENDATIONS
6.1 Introduction
This chapter presents the conclusion based on the findings and recommendations based on both
the study findings and other relevant literature considered necessary and vital to be used in future
to improve the study situation.
6.2 Conclusion
This study has revealed that a lot more needs to be done by different stakeholders to ensure that
the Mothers’ Union objective of effective children’s ministry is achieved.
6.4 Recommendations
Mothers’ Union members need to get training on how to lead children in a Godly way. This is
because they are the foundation of the church and are very dependable in the church and the
family.
The Mothers’ Union members have mandate to teach children and mobilize themselves to know
the value of children in the church. Therefore, the researcher recommends that Mothers’ Union
in Kasindaga Deanery, Diocese of Lweru need to develop a church membership and begin
discipleship classes for children.
Not only that but also, there should be a mass sensitization about the importance of effective
children’s ministry in Kasindaga Deanery, Diocese of Lweru so that the members of Mothers’
Union and other congregants can join hands to expand and improve the children’s ministry.
There is need to encourage parents to bring up their children in the Christian faith and life of
church, and especially in kasindaga denary Lweru diocese.
